verbatim.problem_statement: If the right rooms are facing south, a house is bright and sunny and cheerful; if the wrong rooms are facing south, the house is dark and gloomy.
verbatim.solution_statement: Place the most important rooms along the south edge of the building, and spread the building out along the east-west axis. Fine tune the arrangement so that the proper rooms are exposed to the south-east and the south-west sun. For example: give the common area a full southern exposure, bedrooms south-east, porch south-west. For most climates, this means the shape of the building is elongated east-west.

forces.name: solar access vs. programmatic arrangement
forces.pole_a: the need to place the most-used rooms where direct sunlight can reach them throughout the day
forces.pole_b: the competing organisational logic of the intimacy gradient and functional adjacencies that may pull rooms away from the south edge
forces.description: The desire to optimise sunlight in key rooms conflicts with the tendency to arrange rooms according to function or privacy without regard to orientation.
forces.resolved_by: deliberately positioning the most important rooms along the south edge and elongating the building east-west so that morning, midday, and afternoon sun can be distributed across different room types

forces.name: thermal comfort in winter vs. overheating in summer
forces.pole_a: the need to admit low winter sun for warmth and brightness
forces.pole_b: the need to exclude high summer sun to prevent overheating
forces.description: A building's orientation and shape must simultaneously capture winter solar gain and resist summer solar gain.
forces.resolved_by: elongating the building along the east-west axis, which Olgyay's data shows is optimal across all climates for balancing summer and winter thermal performance

forces.name: interior brightness vs. room depth
forces.pole_a: the desire for sunlit, cheerful interiors with direct sun penetration
forces.pole_b: the structural and spatial tendency to build deep floor plates that leave interior rooms permanently in shadow
forces.description: Deeper buildings accommodate more programme but condemn many rooms to permanent darkness; shallow south-facing rooms maximise sunlight but constrain plan depth.
forces.resolved_by: distributing important rooms along the south edge in a relatively shallow plan, ensuring direct sun reaches occupied spaces throughout the day

forces.name: time-of-day use vs. fixed orientation
forces.pole_a: different rooms are used at different times of day and benefit from sun at those specific times (breakfast nook in morning, porch in evening)
forces.pole_b: a building has a single fixed orientation that cannot shift to follow the sun
forces.description: The sun's east-to-west arc means a single south orientation cannot serve all rooms equally; rooms used at specific times need exposure to SE or SW as appropriate.
forces.resolved_by: fine-tuning room placement along the south-east to south-west arc so that bedrooms face south-east for morning sun, common areas face due south for midday, and porches face south-west for evening sun

typed_rules.rationale: Olgyay's data shows it is always best to orient the long axis east-west across all climates tested
typed_rules.source_text: Note that it is always best to orient the long axis east-west.

typed_rules.preferred_value: most important rooms along south edge
typed_rules.rationale: Direct sunlight has the greatest effect on room quality; placing important rooms elsewhere deprives them of this benefit
typed_rules.source_text: Place the most important rooms along the south edge of the building

typed_rules.rationale: Common/family areas are used throughout the day and benefit from maximum solar access
typed_rules.source_text: give the common area a full southern exposure

typed_rules.rationale: Bedrooms are used in the morning; south-east exposure captures morning sun
Porches are used in the late afternoon and evening; south-west exposure captures evening sun
Composite optimum east-west elongation for cool climates balancing summer and winter thermal performance

typed_rules.rationale: Composite optimum east-west elongation for temperate climates
Composite optimum east-west elongation for hot-arid climates

adjacency_rules.note: Pattern 105 establishes the building's southern orientation as a prerequisite; Pattern 128 refines the internal room arrangement within that framework
The intimacy gradient determines the distribution of public and private rooms; indoor sunlight assigns solar exposure within that gradient
Reinforces south-east bedroom placement to capture morning sun
Sunny outdoor place is opened from the south-facing indoor rooms
Storage and garages are placed to the north, freeing the south edge for habitable rooms
Outdoor rooms are placed directly outside south-facing indoor rooms

Work bench or desk oriented toward the sun in workspace enclosure

failure_modes.description: When important rooms are placed on the north side of the building, they receive no direct sunlight and remain permanently dark and gloomy regardless of other design moves.
failure_modes.symptom: interior feels dark, cold, and cheerless; occupants avoid the room or use artificial light during the day
failure_modes.source_text: if the wrong rooms are facing south, the house is dark and gloomy

failure_modes.description: When a designer allows functional or privacy considerations to override solar placement without compensating, key living spaces lose the benefit of direct sun for most of the day.
failure_modes.symptom: rooms that should be cheerful and warm are dim; occupants feel the building is oppressive
failure_modes.source_text: people may forget about it, and get confused by other considerations. The fact is that very few things have so much effect on the feeling inside a room as the sun shining into it.

failure_modes.description: When the building is oriented with its long axis north-south rather than east-west, fewer rooms can access the south edge and the building performs thermally worse in both summer and winter across all climate types.
failure_modes.symptom: excessive summer overheating and winter heat loss; most rooms face east or west rather than south
failure_modes.source_text: Note that it is always best to orient the long axis east-west.

failure_modes.description: When all south-facing rooms receive identical due-south exposure regardless of their time-of-use, rooms used in the morning (bedrooms) receive weak low sun in the afternoon, and evening spaces miss the late sun entirely.
failure_modes.symptom: bedrooms are stuffy and bright in the afternoon when unoccupied; porches are dark in the evening when used
failure_modes.source_text: Fine tune the arrangement so that the proper rooms are exposed to the south-east and the south-west sun.
